 Asiatic Cheetah]]

'Hunting' is the practice of pursuing any living organism, usually wildlife or
feral animals, by humans for food, recreation, or trade. Animals may also hunt
other animal species, but this is usually called predation. In present-day use,
lawful hunting is distinguished from poaching, which is the killing, trapping or
capture of the hunted species contrary to applicable law. The species that are
hunted are referred to as game and are usually mammals and migratory or non-
migratory gamebirds.

Hunting can also involve the elimination of vermin, as a means of pest control
to prevent diseases caused by overpopulation. Hunting advocates state that
hunting can be a necessary component Williams, Ted. "Wanted: More Hunters,"
Audubon magazine, March 2002, [http://classic-
web.archive.org/web/20071013120158/http://magazine.audubon.org/incite/incite020-
3.html copy] retrieved 26 October 2007. of modern wildlife management, for
example, to help maintain a population of healthy animals within an
environment's ecological carrying capacity when natural checks such as predators
are absent. In the United States, wildlife managers are frequently
part of hunting regulatory and licensing bodies, where they help to set rules on
the number, manner and conditions in which game may be hunted.

The pursuit, capture and release, or capture for food of fish is called fishing,
which is not commonly categorised as a form of hunting. Trapping is also usually
considered a separate activity. It is also not considered hunting to pursue
animals without intent to kill them, as in wildlife photography or birdwatching.
The practice of foraging or gathering materials from plants and mushrooms is
also considered separate.

Skillful tracking and acquisition of an elusive target has caused the word hunt
to be used in the vernacular as a metaphor, as in treasure hunting, "bargain
hunting", and even "hunting down corruption and waste".
